\#\#\# User: I am replacing a flat carport roof with PBR metal sheets over 5/8" inch plywood sheathing with underlayment. I know 1/2 inch is strong enough, but I was thinking more of the nailing. Anyway... it's installed.

I plan to install Tyvek 200 underlayment using 3/4" cap nails, and 1\-1/2" cap nails where the joists are.

For the PBR I have the same, 1\-1/2" metal to wood screws for the joists, and 3/4 for the metal to metal ribs, so I don't see any protrusions there unless I don't hit a joist which is possible.

Since it's a carport, of course when you look up at the bottom, you will see any screws protruding out. There will be quite a few. I guess I could live with them if I had to but I don't really want to.

**Question:** Is it OK to cut off (*either with my cutters or rotary tool*) the tips of any protruding screws or nails? Will it hurt the "holding power?"

FYI i am in Los Angeles. We don't get hurricanes etc. I looked at the high wind history for the last 20 years and it never got above 35 MPH.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: After chatting with my contractor buddy, I just decided to use normal 1\.5 cap nails only where the joists are, which are 16 OC. Any other places that need it I will just use Tack 1/2 Staples.I will also tape the edges down with my fantastic 3M flashing tape to the drip edge I will have nailed down. I think that will do the trick, and not have to cut any nail heads off. It will have metal PBR on top of it anyway in a few weeks. I don't see it going anywhere.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When installing a metal roof on a carport in an area with low wind speeds, which of the following methods is most appropriate for securing the underlayment while minimizing visible fasteners from below?

A) Use 3/4" cap nails throughout the entire roof surface, including between joists
B) Use 1-1/2" cap nails throughout the entire roof surface, including between joists
C) Use 1-1/2" cap nails only at joists spaced 16" on center, and 1/2" staples elsewhere as needed
D) Use 3/4" cap nails at joists and 1-1/2" cap nails between joists

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most appropriate method is to use 1-1/2" cap nails only at joists spaced 16" on center, and 1/2" staples elsewhere as needed. This approach provides adequate fastening at structural points (joists) while minimizing visible fasteners from below. The use of staples between joists allows for additional securing of the underlayment without protruding through the plywood. This method balances the need for proper attachment with aesthetic concerns, particularly important for a carport where the underside is visible. Additionally, taping the edges with flashing tape to the drip edge provides extra security without adding visible fasteners.

\#\#\# User: I'm running Magento 1\.7\.0\.2 and have noticed strange behavior with the `adminhtml/session` messaging system:

```
Mage::getSingleton('adminhtml/session')->addSuccess("Message"); //or addError();

```

If you have two pages open in the backend and **page 1** calls this function, upon refreshing **page 2** (granted that this is done prior to **page 1** completing it's refresh), the message will be rendered on **page 2**.

**How to reproduce:**

1. Refresh all caches (`System` → `Cache Management` → `Select All` → `Refresh`
2. Immediately open Magento's order page (`Sales` → `Orders`)

You'll now notice that the *Orders* page has the success message rendered, something along the lines of:

> 9 cache type(s) refreshed.

See the image below where this message is rendered on the *Orders* page

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/9ijFL.png)

Has anybody else experienced this behavior? I'm trying to establish whether this is brought about by **my** specific instance of Magento as a result of third party extensions or whether it exists in Magento's **core**.

If the latter, does anybody perhaps know of a fix for this? I know it may not seem very high priority, but there are instances where this behavior could be detrimental to site functionality.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is somehow a feature. Here is how `addError`, `addSuccess`, `addNotice`, `addWarning` work.  

The message you give as a parameter for those methods are added to the session.  

when a page is viewed, Magento checks in the session for any messages.  

If there are any, they are displayed and removed from the session. 

So when you do an action (like refreshing cache types for example) and the action is finished, but the redirect is not complete, it means you will have the messages in the session already and refreshing any other page will display them and remove them from session. 

I don't think there is a way to "fix" this. This also happens on frontend if you move fast enough.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: In Magento 1.7.0.2, when using the adminhtml/session messaging system, what happens if you perform an action on one admin page that triggers a success message, and then quickly refresh a different admin page before the first page completes its refresh?

A) The success message will only appear on the original page where the action was performed
B) The success message will appear on both pages simultaneously
C) The success message will appear on the second page that was refreshed, even though the action wasn't performed there
D) The success message won't appear on any page

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: This behavior is actually a feature of Magento's adminhtml/session messaging system. When a success message (or any other type of message) is added to the session using methods like addSuccess() or addError(), it is stored in the session data. When any admin page is loaded, Magento checks the session for pending messages. If found, these messages are displayed and then removed from the session.

In the scenario described, if you perform an action on one page (like refreshing caches) that adds a success message to the session, but then quickly refresh a different admin page before the original page has completed its refresh, the success message will appear on the second page. This happens because the message is already in the session, and the second page load retrieves and displays it before the first page has a chance to do so.

This behavior can also occur on the frontend if a user navigates quickly enough between pages. While it may seem counterintuitive, it's part of how Magento handles session-based messaging across the entire admin (and frontend) interface.

\#\#\# User: This is a version of [Windows XP: Can I paste plain text by default](https://superuser.com/questions/11641/windows-xp-can-i-paste-plain-text-by-default) for **Mac** users. This drives me insane as well. 

Whenever I cut and paste ***anything*** from one app to another in OS X it carries formatting with it. The only exception is when using a text editor like TextMate. I don't want text I copied from a website or Pages to paste with formatting in iChat, etc.

Does anyone know a way I can turn this off by default, or is there an app that will do it for me?

Thanks for your help.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Here you go:
[https://www.engadget.com/2009\-07\-07\-tuaw\-tip\-paste\-without\-formatting\-by\-default.html](https://www.engadget.com/2009-07-07-tuaw-tip-paste-without-formatting-by-default.html)
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/90kVO.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/90kVO.png)

> There's an answer, thanks to the Keyboard \& Mouse pane in System Preferences. If you click the Keyboard Shortcuts tab, you can assign "Paste Without Formatting" and/or "Paste and Match Style" to Command \+ V for all applications. Just click the `+` button under the list, type in the name of the appropriate menu items, and press ⌘\-V in the Keyboard Shortcut box.
> 
> 
> One note: [Panic](https://panic.com/) designer Neven Mrgan found that using this tip means you [won't be able to paste images](https://twitter.com/mrgan/status/2521320331) into iChat using Command \+ V. Dragging and dropping (or choosing Paste from the Edit menu) still works, though. Update: If you [explicitly add ⌘\-V in as a shortcut for Paste](https://twitter.com/mrgan/status/2521860808) that's specific to iChat, you can restore the image paste capability without breaking the global shortcut.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: On macOS, which of the following methods allows you to set up a system-wide keyboard shortcut to paste without formatting by default?

A) Install a third-party application specifically designed for plain text pasting
B) Modify the Terminal preferences to always paste as plain text
C) Use the Keyboard & Mouse pane in System Preferences to assign a custom shortcut
D) Edit the .plist files in the Library folder to override default paste behavior

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct method to set up a system-wide shortcut for pasting without formatting is to use the Keyboard & Mouse pane in System Preferences. Specifically, you would:

1. Open System Preferences
2. Go to the Keyboard & Mouse pane
3. Click on the Keyboard Shortcuts tab
4. Click the '+' button under the list
5. Type in "Paste Without Formatting" or "Paste and Match Style"
6. Press Command-V (⌘-V) in the Keyboard Shortcut box

This method allows you to override the default paste behavior across all applications. Option A is incorrect because while third-party apps exist, they're not necessary for this functionality. Option B is incorrect because Terminal preferences wouldn't affect system-wide behavior. Option D is incorrect and potentially dangerous, as directly editing .plist files is not the recommended approach for this task.

It's worth noting that this solution may have some limitations, such as affecting the ability to paste images in certain applications like iChat, but workarounds exist for specific apps if needed.

\#\#\# User: I am currently running for the Board of Education in my little town and am working on my candidate statement for the election handbook that the Department of Elections produces. I sent what I had to a friend who is a great editor and she questioned the following bit of text:

> For some, sports are a motivation to do well in school; we need to ensure that the artistically\- and scientifically\-minded students have as much encouragement and support as the athletically\-gifted students.

Specifically, she asked about the "adverbs *artistically* and *scientifically* versus adjectives *artistic* and *scientific* modifying *minded*". She noted that she thought the adverbs were correct, but wasn't sure why. (I'm not sure why either, but that applies to almost everything anyway.)

So I went and looked up both the adjective and adverb forms in the Oxford Dictionaries to see what I could find out. Here are those definitions:

> ***[artistic](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/artistic)***
> 
> 
> **ADJECTIVE**
> 
> 
> 1. Having or revealing natural creative skill.
> 
> 
> *‘my lack of artistic ability’*
> 
> 
> ***[artistically](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/artistically)***
> 
> 
> **ADVERB**
> 
> 
> 1. As regards art or artists; from an artistic point of view.
> 
> 
> *‘the Soviet film industry was artistically limited by outside pressures’*  
> 
> *‘her home was cosy and so artistically decorated for Christmas’*
> 
> 
> ***[scientific](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/scientific)***
> 
> 
> **ADJECTIVE**
> 
> 
> 1. Based on or characterized by the methods and principles of science.
> 
> 
> *‘the scientific study of earthquakes’*
> 
> 
> ***[scientifically](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/scientifically)***
> 
> 
> **ADVERB**
> 
> 
> 1. By means of scientific methods and principles.
> 
> 
> *‘scientifically proven treatments’*  
> 
> *‘both theories can be explained scientifically’*
> 
> 
> 1\.1 In a way that relates to or is used in science.
> 
> 
> *‘scientifically minded people’*  
> 
> *‘a scientifically important site’*

The sample sentences for *scientifically* actually include the exact phrase I'm using \-\- *scientifically minded* \-\- so I'm pretty sure I'm correct in using the adverb forms. When I looked up minded, it too had the same adverbial example:

> ***[minded](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/minded)***
> 
> 
> **ADJECTIVE**
> 
> 
> 1. *\[in combination or with submodifier]* Inclined to think in a particular way.
> 
> 
> *‘liberal\-minded scholars’*  
> 
> *‘I'm not scientifically minded’*
> 
> 
> 1\.1 *\[in combination]* Interested in or enthusiastic about a particular thing.
> 
> 
> *‘conservation\-minded citizens’*

However, I note that the other examples here use adjectives: *liberal\-minded* instead of *liberally\-minded* and *conservation\-minded* instead of *conservationally\-minded*. I also note that the examples that use an adjective are hyphenated while the one with an adverb is not. 

So my question is, why do some *\-minded* phrases take adjectives while others take adverbs? Also, is the correlation between type of modifier and the presence of a hyphen significant or coincidental?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: According to the [Collins English Dictionary](https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/minded_2),"\-minded" combines with 3 parts of speech: adjectives, adverbs and nouns. 

> 1. "\-minded" combines with **adjectives** to form words that describe someone's **character, attitude, opinions, or intelligence**: *These
>  are evil\-minded people.*
> 2. "\-minded" combines with **adverbs** to form adjectives that indicate that **someone is interested in a particular subject or is
>  able to think in a particular way**: *I am not an academically\-minded
>  person*.
> 3. "\-minded" combines with **nouns** to form adjectives that indicate that **someone thinks a particular thing is important or cares a lot
>  about it**: *He is seen as more business\-minded than his predecessor.*

As for the hyphen, it should be used with the combining form "\-minded".

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses the "-minded" combining form according to the Collins English Dictionary guidelines?

A) The environmentally-minded citizens organized a cleanup event.
B) The company is looking for business minded individuals to join their team.
C) Her creative-minded approach to problem-solving impressed the board.
D) We need more science minded students in our advanced programs.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
A) is correct because it uses an adverb (environmentally) with "-minded" to indicate interest in a particular subject, and it includes the necessary hyphen.

B) is incorrect because it's missing the required hyphen between "business" and "minded."

C) is incorrect because it uses an adjective (creative) instead of an adverb. The correct form would be "creatively-minded."

D) is incorrect for two reasons: it's missing the required hyphen, and it uses a noun (science) instead of an adverb. The correct form would be "scientifically-minded."

This question tests understanding of the different parts of speech that can combine with "-minded," as well as the proper use of hyphens in these constructions.

\#\#\# User: lately I have been working a lot on my desktop computer, 3 months, leaving behind my laptop. I've been using Ubuntu Karmic Koala a lot, working with many applications and installing lots of useful software. When the new year will begin I will have to hit the road again and leave behing my desktop. That's a pity since I'm enjoying my setup a lot. So I was wondering if is it there a way to transfer all my Linux setup on my laptop, with all the same settings (except hardware of course) and applications (libraries, development tools...). I thought of just copying the partition with clonezilla but I even asked myself if this will actually work. Then there is the not so secondary problem that I'd have to shrink the partition. So, do you have advice on this?

Happy new year to all :D

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you've mostly been using the built in package management to install applications, I would suggest simply dumping the list of packages installed on your desktop and installing them on your laptop. You should then be able to just copy over your $HOME folder, and your apps should have all their settings back.

[This question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/174839/clone-debian-ubuntu-installation) on stackoverflow has a couple of ways of doing just that.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given StackExchange documentation:

Question: A developer has been using Ubuntu Karmic Koala on their desktop computer for 3 months and wants to transfer their entire setup, including applications and settings, to their laptop. Which of the following approaches is the most efficient and recommended method to achieve this?

A) Use Clonezilla to copy the entire partition from the desktop to the laptop, then shrink the partition to fit the laptop's storage.

B) Manually reinstall all applications on the laptop and copy over the entire /etc directory from the desktop to maintain system-wide settings.

C) Generate a list of installed packages from the desktop, install them on the laptop, then copy over the $HOME folder to restore user-specific settings.

D) Create a full system backup of the desktop using rsync, then restore it on the laptop, adjusting hardware-specific configurations manually.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most efficient and recommended approach. By generating a list of installed packages from the desktop and installing them on the laptop, you ensure that all applications are properly installed through the package management system. This avoids potential conflicts or incompatibilities that might arise from directly copying system files or entire partitions. Copying the $HOME folder afterwards restores all user-specific settings and configurations. This method provides a clean installation on the laptop while maintaining the user's customized environment and installed applications.

Option A (using Clonezilla) could potentially cause issues due to hardware differences between the desktop and laptop. Option B (manually reinstalling and copying /etc) is time-consuming and may introduce system-wide configuration conflicts. Option D (full system backup and restore) is overly complex and may require significant post-restore adjustments.

\#\#\# User: I am self\-studying from Richard Bass's Real Analysis book, available [here](http://bass.math.uconn.edu/rags010213.pdf). 

I am not sure about Exercise 3\.2:

> Suppose $(X,\\mathcal{A})$ is a measurable space and $\\mu$ is a
>  non\-negative set function that is finitely additive and such that
>  $\\mu(\\varnothing) \= 0$ and $\\mu(X)\<\\infty$. Suppose that whenever $A\_i$ is a sequence of sets in $\\mathcal{A}$ which decrease to $\\varnothing$, then $\\lim\_{i\\to\\infty}\\mu(A\_i)\=0$. Show that $\\mu$ is a measure.

In order to show that $\\mu$ is a measure, all that remains to be shown is for any countable collection of pairwise disjoint sets $\\{B\_i\\}\_{ i \=1,2,3\\ldots}$, 
$$\\mu(\\cup\_i B\_i)\=\\sum\_i \\mu(B\_i).$$

My attempt:

Let $\\{B\_i\\}\_{ i \=1,2,3\\ldots}$ be a countable collection of pairwise disjoint sets. Then consider $\\cup\_{i\=n}^{\\infty}B\_i \\downarrow \\varnothing$. It follows that $\\lim\_{n\\to\\infty}\\mu(\\cup\_{i\=n}^{\\infty}B\_i)\=0$. We can rewrite this as
$$\\lim\_{n\\to\\infty}\\mu\\left(\\cup\_{i\=1}^{\\infty}B\_i\-\\cup\_{i\=1}^{n\-1}B\_i\\right)\=0,$$
so by the algebra of limits
$$\\mu\\left(\\cup\_{i\=1}^{\\infty}B\_i\\right)\=\\lim\_{n\\to\\infty}\\mu(\\cup\_{i\=1}^{n\-1}B\_i)\=\\lim\_{n\\to\\infty}\\mu(\\cup\_{i\=1}^n B\_i)\=\\lim\_{n\\to\\infty}\\sum\_{i\=1}^n\\mu(B\_i)\=\\sum\_{i\=1}^{\\infty}\\mu(B\_i).$$

Questions:

(1\) Is this proof correct? (In particular I am not sure that $\\cup\_{i\=n}^{\\infty}B\_i$ does decrease to $\\varnothing$.)

(2\) I do not appear to have used $\\mu(X)\<\\infty$ anywhere. Why is this needed?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You cannot write $\\mu (A\\setminus B)$ as $\\mu (A)\-\\mu (B)$ for infinite measures (for $B \\subset A$). That is where the assumption $\\mu (X) \<\\infty $ is required. Otherwise your proof is correct. It should be clear that $\\cup\_{i\=n}^{\\infty }B\_i$ is decreasing. Suppose there is a point $x$ in the intersection. Then $x$ would belong to infinitely many of the sets $B\_i$. But no point can belong to more than one of these sets, so the intersection is empty.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider a non-negative set function μ on a measurable space (X,A) that is finitely additive with μ(∅) = 0 and μ(X) < ∞. If for any sequence of sets Ai in A that decrease to ∅, lim(i→∞) μ(Ai) = 0, which of the following statements is NOT necessary to prove that μ is a measure?

A) Show that μ(∪Bi) = Σμ(Bi) for any countable collection of pairwise disjoint sets {Bi}
B) Prove that ∪(i=n to ∞)Bi decreases to ∅ for any countable collection of pairwise disjoint sets {Bi}
C) Demonstrate that μ(A\B) = μ(A) - μ(B) for any sets A and B in A where B ⊂ A
D) Verify that lim(n→∞) μ(∪(i=1 to n)Bi) = Σ(i=1 to ∞)μ(Bi) for any countable collection of pairwise disjoint sets {Bi}

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Statement C is not necessary to prove that μ is a measure in this context. The equality μ(A\B) = μ(A) - μ(B) is not generally true for all measures, especially when dealing with infinite measures. The condition μ(X) < ∞ is given to ensure we're working with a finite measure, which allows us to use properties of finite additivity without needing this specific equality.

Statements A, B, and D are all important steps in proving that μ is a measure:
A) This is the key property of countable additivity that needs to be shown.
B) This step is crucial for applying the given condition about sequences decreasing to ∅.
D) This demonstrates the connection between finite additivity and countable additivity.

\#\#\# User: I'm having a hard time figuring out how the following circuit works.

I studied the theory behind instrumentation amplifiers and from what I learned they are used to measure a difference between two voltage inputs and amplify the signal.

Now in the following configuration I don't understand the roles of the three amplifiers (for example, why is A3 buffering Vref?).

![Circuit layout](https://i.imgur.com/uaU7aqc.png)

I'm not looking for a solution, but just an explanation of how it works.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I found what I wanted after reading documentation for the xspice module available in ngspice. It allows me to write models for my digital components in C and then simulate peripheral discrete components using existing spice models for transistors, resistors etc. I'm still experimenting with this feature but so far it has been very promising because I can model any firmware based digital controller in between inputs and outputs of a digital component defined in the schematic.

Here is a small throwaway example of a custom pwm component:
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/qQYlH.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/qQYlH.png)

I then export this as a spice netlist from kicad:

```
* Sheet Name: /
A1  Net-_A1-Pad1_ GND Net-_A1-Pad3_ Net-_A1-Pad4_ MKPWM01
V1  Net-_A1-Pad1_ GND 3.3v
R3  OUT GND 50k
R2  Net-_A1-Pad3_ GND 10k
R1  Net-_A1-Pad1_ Net-_A1-Pad3_ 10k
C1  OUT GND 10n
R4  OUT Net-_A1-Pad4_ 50k

.end

```

Then I add a little wrapper script where I add ngspice commands for my circuit:

```
.model mkpwm01 mkpwm01 (freq = 100)

.include "spice_test.cir"

.control
tran 1ms 100ms
plot v(OUT)
.endc

.end

```

And finally I add code model for mkpwm component under src/xspice/icm and then compile ngspice:

```
void cm_d_mkpwm01(ARGS) {               
    if (ANALYSIS == DC || ANALYSIS == TRANSIENT) {
        double out = sin(TIME * PARAM(freq) * 2.f * M_PI);

        if(out > 0) out = INPUT(vcc);   
        else out = INPUT(gnd);          

        OUTPUT(out) = out;              
    }   
}       

```

And the model definition (.ifs) file:

```
NAME_TABLE:

Spice_Model_Name:      mkpwm01          
C_Function_Name:       cm_d_mkpwm01     
Description:           "pwm generator"  

PORT_TABLE:

Port_Name:           vcc                gnd             in                 out
Description:         "vcc"              "gnd"           "input"            "output"
Direction:           in                 in              in                 out
Default_Type:        v                  v               v                  v
Allowed_Types:       [v]                [v]             [v]                [v]
Vector:              no                 no              no                 no
Vector_Bounds:       -                  -               -                  -
Null_Allowed:        no                 no              no                 no

PARAMETER_TABLE:

Parameter_Name:     freq                
Description:        "frequency"         
Data_Type:          real
Default_Value:      1                   
Limits:             [1e-12 -]           
Vector:              no                 
Vector_Bounds:       -                  
Null_Allowed:       yes           

```

Then finally running the wrapper script produces the result:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/rkxJb.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/rkxJb.png)

Very happy so far. Now time to simulate a more complex circuit :\-)

Note: I originally added the xspice component as a digital component but that did not work because I got error "node can not be both digital and analog" so I had to change the pins to be analog (type v). The ngspice manual explains different pin types. Also the duty cycle input is not really implemented in the code.. Anyway, I still probably have a lot to learn how xspice api works but so far I think I found exactly what I need and hopefully this helps someone to start using ngspice for customized circuit simulation.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In the context of using XSPICE with ngspice for custom circuit simulation, which of the following statements is correct?

A) The .ifs file is used to define the C function for the custom component's behavior.
B) Digital components can be directly implemented in XSPICE without any modifications.
C) The .model command in the wrapper script is used to compile the custom component.
D) The PORT_TABLE in the .ifs file defines the inputs, outputs, and their characteristics for the custom component.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because the .ifs file is used for model definition, not for the C function implementation. The C function is defined in a separate file under src/xspice/icm.

B) is incorrect. The documentation mentions that digital components caused an error ("node can not be both digital and analog"), so the pins had to be changed to analog type.

C) is incorrect. The .model command in the wrapper script is used to declare the model, not compile it. Compilation is done separately for ngspice with the custom component included.

D) is correct. The PORT_TABLE in the .ifs file indeed defines the inputs, outputs, and their characteristics (such as direction, type, and whether null values are allowed) for the custom component.

\#\#\# User: Lets say you have to write some code to fix a bug that on first glance by another engineer would seem weird or unnecessary.

Would it be good or bad form to put the code in a method named for example "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears" or just name it "forceSpecifiedWindowPosition" and then add a comment about why you are doing this when calling the method?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I think it's better to name methods based on what you are trying to accomplish rather than how, as part of the whole public interface / private implementation thing. So, all else being equal, I would call it "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears". 

However, all else might not be equal. Will the parameters make sense equally with both names? If you have to pass the window position to "forceSpecifiedWindowPosition" it makes sense, but not so much for "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears", which sounds like it would either be passed nothing or a window. Also, if forcing the window position could be considered a side\-effect (sounds like no \- it's the effect you want) then "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears" would have results that might be unexpected from the name, so I wouldn't name it that.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: When fixing a bug that requires code that might seem unusual at first glance, which of the following approaches is generally considered the best practice for method naming and documentation?

A) Use a descriptive method name like "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears" without additional comments

B) Use a generic method name like "forceSpecifiedWindowPosition" with a detailed comment explaining the purpose when calling the method

C) Use a descriptive method name like "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears" and also include a comment explaining the purpose when calling the method

D) Use a generic method name like "forceSpecifiedWindowPosition" without any additional comments

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: The best practice is to use a descriptive method name that clearly indicates the purpose of the code, such as "preventWindowFromJumpingWhenKeyboardAppears". This approach follows the principle of naming methods based on what they accomplish rather than how they do it. It provides immediate clarity to other developers without requiring additional comments. However, it's important to consider the context, such as whether the parameters make sense with the chosen name and if there are any potential side effects that might not be obvious from the name alone. In some cases, a more generic name with a comment might be more appropriate, but generally, a clear, descriptive name is preferred.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An engineer is working with an ATTINY85 microcontroller and notices that when setting OCR0A or OCR0B to 0, the corresponding pins (PB0 and PB1) don't go fully LOW, but instead output a weak signal. What is the most likely explanation for this behavior, and how can it be addressed?

A) The ATTINY85 has a hardware defect causing this issue. The microcontroller should be replaced.

B) The PWM mode for Timer0 on ATTINY85 cannot reach 0% duty cycle. To achieve a fully OFF state, the output should be inverted and the OCR0A/OCR0B values should be set to 0xFF instead of 0x00.

C) The connected LEDs have a very low forward voltage, causing them to light up even with minimal current. Higher value resistors should be used.

D) The NPN3904 transistors are faulty and allowing some leakage current. They should be replaced with higher quality transistors.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the ATTINY85 datasheet, the PWM mode for Timer0 cannot reach a true 0% duty cycle. When OCR0A or OCR0B is set to 0, it results in a narrow spike for each timer clock cycle rather than a constant LOW output. To achieve a fully OFF state, the output should be inverted (by changing the COM0A[1:0] or COM0B[1:0] bits in TCCR0A register), and then setting OCR0A or OCR0B to 0xFF will result in a constant LOW output. This is a characteristic of the microcontroller's timer/counter operation, not a defect or issue with external components.

\#\#\# User: Let $C\_d$ be a unit edge\-length cube in $d$ dimensions.
I would like to orient it ("tilt" it) so that the vertical (last) coordinates
of its $2^d$ vertices are maximally separated, in the sense
that the minimum vertical distance between any two vertices is maximized
over all orientations.

For $C\_2$ (in standard orientation, edges parallel to
Cartesian axes), tilting $\\arctan \\frac{1}{2} \\approx 26\.6^\\circ$ separates
the vertices by $\\delta\=1/\\sqrt{5} \\approx 0\.447$:

---

![](https://i.stack.imgur.com/63MLg.jpg)

---

For $C\_3$ (in standard orientation), I believe that rotating the vector $(0,0,1\)$ to lie on
the vector $(\\frac{1}{4},\\frac{1}{2},1\)$ results in a vertex separation of $\\delta\=1/\\sqrt{21} \\approx 0\.218$:

---

![](https://i.stack.imgur.com/HicKE.jpg)

---

My question is:

> **Q**. What is the generalization to $C\_d$ for $d\>3$? What is the largest
>  vertex separation $\\delta$ achievable?
>  Can one always achieve a uniform vertex separation
>  (the same $\\delta$ between each vertically adjacent pair),
>  as in $C\_2$ and $C\_3$?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Given a unit vector $u \\in \\mathbb R^d$, the "heights" of vertices of the $n$\-cube where $u$ is regarded as the vertical direction are the sums of subsets of the entries of $u$. Thus the minimum separation is the minimum difference
between the sums of two distinct subsets of these entries. If you take 
$$u \= \[1,2,\\ldots,2^{d\-1}]/\\sqrt{1^2 \+ 2^2 \+ \\ldots (2^{d\-1})^2} \= \\sqrt{\\dfrac{3}{4^d\-1}}\[1,2,\\ldots,2^{d\-1}]$$
you get uniform separation of $\\sqrt{3/(4^d\-1\)}$.

14.answer:
Here's a multi-part question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider a d-dimensional unit cube Cd. When oriented to maximize the vertical separation of its vertices, which of the following statements is correct?

A) The optimal orientation vector u is always [1,1,...,1]/√d, regardless of dimension.

B) The minimum vertical separation δ between vertices is given by 1/√(d+1) for all dimensions d.

C) The optimal orientation vector u is [1,2,...,2^(d-1)]/√(1^2 + 2^2 + ... + (2^(d-1))^2), resulting in a uniform separation of √(3/(4^d-1)) between vertically adjacent vertex pairs.

D) It is impossible to achieve a uniform separation between vertically adjacent vertex pairs for dimensions d > 3.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation provides the optimal orientation vector u = [1,2,...,2^(d-1)]/√(1^2 + 2^2 + ... + (2^(d-1))^2), which can be simplified to √(3/(4^d-1))[1,2,...,2^(d-1)]. This orientation results in a uniform separation of √(3/(4^d-1)) between vertically adjacent vertex pairs for any dimension d.

Option A is incorrect because the optimal orientation vector is not [1,1,...,1]/√d, but rather has increasing powers of 2 as components.

Option B is incorrect as the given formula 1/√(d+1) does not match the correct separation of √(3/(4^d-1)).

Option D is incorrect because the documentation shows that uniform separation is achievable for all dimensions, not just for d ≤ 3.

A) Modify the docker-compose.yml file to include a "zero_downtime" flag

\#\#\# Top Answer: `--dns` works for `docker run` but not for `docker build`. So better solution is to adjust the settings globally with 

```
DOCKER_OPTS="--dns=my-private-dns-server-ip --dns=8.8.8.8"

```

On Ubuntu I put this line into `/etc/default/docker`

\#\#\# User: I am just designing my application and I am not sure if I understand SOLID and OOP correctly. Classes should do 1 thing and do it well but from the other hand they should represent real objects we work with. 

In my case I do a feature extraction on a dataset and then I do a machine learning analysis. I assume that I could create three classes

1. FeatureExtractor
2. DataSet
3. Analyser

But the FeatureExtractor class doesnt represent anything, it does something what makes it more of a routine than a class.
It will have just one function that will be used : extract\_features()

Is it correct to create classes that do not represent one thing but do one thing?

EDIT: not sure if it matters but I'm using Python

And if extract\_features() would look like that: is it worth to create a special class to hold that method?

```py
def extract_features(df):
    extr = PhrasesExtractor()
    extr.build_vocabulary(df["Text"].tolist())

    sent = SentimentAnalyser()
    sent.load()

    df = add_features(df, extr.features)
    df = mark_features(df, extr.extract_features)
    df = drop_infrequent_features(df)
    df = another_processing1(df)
    df = another_processing2(df)
    df = another_processing3(df)
    df = set_sentiment(df, sent.get_sentiment)
    return df

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Classes should do 1 thing and do it well

Yes, that is generally a good approach.

> but from the other hand they should represent real object we work with.

No, that is a IMHO common misunderstanding. A good beginner's access to OOP is often *"start with objects representing things from the real world"*, that is true. 

However, you **should not stop with this**!

Classes can (and should) be used to structure your program in various ways. Modeling objects from the real world is one aspect of this, but not the only one. Creating modules or components for a specific task is another sensible use case for classes. A "feature extractor" is probably such a module, and even it contains only one **public** method `extract_features()`, I would be astonished if if does not also contain a lot of private methods and maybe some shared state. So having a class `FeatureExtractor` will introduce a natural location for these private methods.

*Side note: in languages like Python which support a separate module concept one can also use a module `FeatureExtractor` for this, but in the context of this question, this is IMHO a negligible difference.*

Moreover, a "feature extractor" can be imagined as "a person or bot which extracts features". That is an abstract "thing", maybe not a thing you will find in the real world, but the name itself is a useful abstraction, which gives everyone a notion of what the responsibility of that class is. So I disagree that this class does not "represent anything".

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: In object-oriented programming, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the creation and use of classes?

A) Classes should only represent concrete objects from the real world and nothing else.

B) Classes should always have multiple public methods to be considered properly designed.

C) Classes can be used to structure programs in various ways, including modeling real-world objects and creating modules for specific tasks.

D) Creating a class for a single-method operation like feature extraction is against SOLID principles and should be avoided.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The correct answer is C. While it's common for beginners to start by modeling real-world objects as classes, this is not the only valid use for classes in object-oriented programming. Classes can and should be used to structure programs in various ways, including creating modules or components for specific tasks.

Option A is incorrect because classes are not limited to representing only concrete real-world objects. They can also represent abstract concepts or functional units within a program.

Option B is incorrect because the number of public methods is not a definitive measure of good class design. A well-designed class can have a single public method if that's all that's needed to fulfill its role.

Option D is incorrect because creating a class for a specific task, even if it has only one public method, can be a valid design choice. It can provide a natural location for related private methods and shared state, and can represent an abstract concept (like "a thing that extracts features").

This question tests understanding of object-oriented design principles beyond the basic concept of modeling real-world objects, emphasizing the flexibility and utility of classes in structuring code.

\#\#\# User: I want to clip two SpatialPolygons on R without success, I followed the article in the disscution [How to perform a true GIS clip of polygons layer using a polygon layer in R?](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/93096/how-to-perform-a-true-gis-clip-of-polygons-layer-using-a-polygon-layer-in-r)

Polygone 01 :

```
> polygone1
class       : SpatialPolygons 
features    : 1 
extent      : -8.673868, 11.98891, 19.43771, 37.09514  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
coord. ref. : +init=epsg:4326 +proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs +ellps=WGS84 +towgs84=0,0,0 

```

Polygone 02 :

```
> Polygone2
class       : SpatialPolygons 
features    : 4 
extent      : 0.665381, 12.35598, 30.72105, 37.50386  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax)
coord. ref. : +init=epsg:4326 +proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs +ellps=WGS84 +towgs84=0,0,0 

```

Code :

```
clip2 <- gIntersection(Polygone1, Polygone2, byid=TRUE)

```

Erreur :

```
Error in RGEOSBinTopoFunc(spgeom1, spgeom2, byid, id, drop_not_poly, "rgeos_intersection") : 
  TopologyException: Input geom 0 is invalid: Self-intersection at or near point 8.1451386683704339 37.192197131616837 at 8.1451386683704339 37.192197131616837

```

Does anyone can help me?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Try:

```
polygone1 <- gBuffer(polygone1, byid=TRUE, width=0)
polygone2 <- gBuffer(polygone2, byid=TRUE, width=0)
clip2 <- gIntersection(Polygone1, Polygone2, byid=TRUE)

```

It is ugly, but it usually solves this kind of problem.

HTH

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: When attempting to clip two SpatialPolygons objects in R using gIntersection(), you encounter a TopologyException error indicating a self-intersection issue. Which of the following approaches is most likely to resolve this problem while maintaining the integrity of the original polygons?

A) Increase the precision of the polygon coordinates using st_set_precision()
B) Apply gBuffer() with a width of 0 to both polygons before using gIntersection()
C) Convert the SpatialPolygons to sf objects and use st_intersection() instead
D) Simplify the polygons using rmapshaper::ms_simplify() before intersection

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct approach to resolve the TopologyException error is to apply gBuffer() with a width of 0 to both polygons before using gIntersection(). This method, while described as "ugly" in the original answer, is often effective in solving self-intersection issues without altering the geometry of the polygons.

Option A (increasing precision) might help in some cases but is not the recommended solution for this specific error.

Option C (converting to sf objects) could work, but it involves changing the data structure and may not directly address the topology issue.

Option D (simplifying the polygons) could potentially remove the self-intersection, but it would alter the original polygon geometries, which may not be desirable.

The gBuffer() approach (option B) is a common workaround in R for fixing topology errors in spatial data without significantly altering the original geometries.

Question: An electrician is working on upgrading an outdoor lighting system for a house built in 1972. The existing setup includes a 2" x 3" rectangular recessed electrical box in aluminum siding. The electrician wants to add a new outdoor light receptacle several feet above the existing box. Which of the following approaches is the most appropriate and code-compliant method to accomplish this task?

A) Install a weather-resistant extension box directly onto the existing recessed box and run conduit from there to the new receptacle location.

B) Replace the entire existing recessed box with a larger, modern outdoor-rated box that can accommodate the new conduit run.

C) Drill a hole through the siding next to the existing box, run the new wiring through the wall cavity, and install a separate box for the new receptacle.

D) Leave the existing box as is, surface-mount a new weather-resistant box next to it, and run exposed conduit between the two boxes and up to the new receptacle location.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: Option A is the most appropriate and code-compliant solution. Using a weather-resistant extension box designed to fit over the existing recessed box allows for a secure connection and proper weatherproofing. This method maintains the integrity of the existing installation while providing a suitable starting point for the new conduit run to the additional receptacle. It minimizes alterations to the building's structure and siding, and ensures a professional, code-compliant installation that properly protects the wiring from the elements.

Option B is excessive and unnecessarily destructive. Option C could potentially violate code by running wires through an unprotected wall cavity and may not be feasible depending on the wall's construction. Option D, while potentially functional, is less aesthetically pleasing and may not provide adequate protection for the wiring connections between the old and new boxes.

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1. Open Adobe Reader.

3. Switch the file view to show icons. This causes Adobe Reader to load (and cache) thumbnails for the files in this folder. If necessary, scroll up and down to make sure all the thumbnails have loaded.

A) Connect an iPhone to the PC and copy PDF files to the DCIM\100Apple folder
B) Use Adobe Reader to open and cache thumbnails, then refresh Windows Explorer
C) Install iTunes and use it to sync PDF files with thumbnail data
D) Modify the Windows Registry to enable PDF thumbnails globally

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B. The documentation outlines a process using Adobe Reader to generate thumbnails for PDF files that can then be viewed in Windows Explorer. This method doesn't require additional software installation or system-wide changes.

Option A is incorrect as it relates to iPhone image storage and doesn't address PDF thumbnails.

Option C is incorrect because iTunes is not mentioned in the documentation and is not necessary for PDF thumbnail generation.

Option D is incorrect as the method described doesn't involve modifying the Windows Registry.

The correct process involves opening Adobe Reader, browsing to the folder with PDFs, switching to icon view to load thumbnails, closing Adobe Reader, and then refreshing the folder in Windows Explorer. This caches the thumbnails for use in Windows Explorer without permanent changes to the system.

\#\#\# User: $\\forall x\\in Q (\\forall y \\in R(y \\notin Q \\to \\frac{x}{y} \\notin Q))$

counterexample: let $x\=0, y\=\\sqrt2$, then $\\frac{0}{\\sqrt2} \= 0 \= \\frac{0}{1} \\in Q$,

but by contrapositive: 
$\\forall x\\in Q (\\forall y \\in R(\\frac{x}{y} \\in Q \\to y \\in Q ))$

Suppose $\\frac{x}{y}$ is rational, then $x \\in Z$ and $y \\in Z$ by definition of rational and any integer is rational, then y \= $\\frac{a}{b}$ for some integers $a$ and $b$.

So the original statement is false because there is a counterexample, but its contrapositive is true and hence the statement is true too.

What am I missing here?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Suppose $\\frac{x}{y}$ is rational, then $x \\in Z$ and $y \\in Z$ by definition of rational

False. If $x\=y\=\\frac12$, then $\\frac{x}{y}$ is rational, but $x\\notin \\mathbb Z$ and $y\\notin\\mathbb Z$.

22.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider the statement: $\forall x\in \mathbb{Q} (\forall y \in \mathbb{R}(y \notin \mathbb{Q} \to \frac{x}{y} \notin \mathbb{Q}))$
Which of the following is true?

A) The statement is always true for all x and y.
B) The statement is false, and its contrapositive is also false.
C) The statement is false, but its contrapositive is true.
D) The statement is true, but there exists a counterexample.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
The statement is false, as demonstrated by the counterexample: let $x=0, y=\sqrt{2}$. Then $y \notin \mathbb{Q}$, but $\frac{x}{y} = \frac{0}{\sqrt{2}} = 0 \in \mathbb{Q}$.

The contrapositive of the statement is:
$\forall x\in \mathbb{Q} (\forall y \in \mathbb{R}(\frac{x}{y} \in \mathbb{Q} \to y \in \mathbb{Q} ))$

This contrapositive is also false. Consider $x=1, y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$. Here, $\frac{x}{y} = \sqrt{2} \notin \mathbb{Q}$, but the implication is still true because the antecedent is false. However, $y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \notin \mathbb{Q}$, violating the consequent.

The error in the original reasoning was assuming that if $\frac{x}{y}$ is rational, then both $x$ and $y$ must be integers, which is not necessarily true.

\#\#\# User: A few times in the past week I will wake up to my furnace turning on, hearing a click when it tries to ignite, then turn off. This will happen for a couple minutes before the furnace quits trying. 

However, after a certain period of time, it will turn on again with no issues. 

What should I do so it doesn't happen ever?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: ***WARNING:**  

Furnaces are expensive, complex pieces of equipment. If you don't have the proper tools and/or knowledge, it's often best to let the professionals handle maintenance and repair.*

Gas Furnace Ignition Sequence:
==============================

1. Thermostat calls for heat.
2. Pilot gas valve opens.
3. Ignition control starts (spark or glow).
4. Pilot gas ignites.
5. Flame sensor detects pilot flame.
6. Main gas valve opens.
7. Main burners ignite.
8. Blower timer starts.
9. Flame sensor detects main burner flame.
10. Blower starts.

High Efficiency Gas Furnace Ignition Sequence:
==============================================

1. Thermostat calls for heat.
2. Draft inducer starts.
3. Vacuum switch detects negative pressure.
4. Pilot valve opens.
5. Ignition control starts (spark or glow).
6. Pilot gas ignites.
7. Flame sensor detects pilot flame.
8. Main gas valve opens.
9. Main burners ignite.
10. Blower timer starts.
11. Flame sensor detects main burner flame.
12. Blower starts.

Ignition Problems:
==================

Vacuum Switch Not Closing
-------------------------

In a high efficiency furnace, if the vacuum switch does not close after a certain timeout. The furnace will shut down, then possibly retry a few times depending on model. If after a given number of tries the switch still does not close, the furnace will enter lock out. Once in lock out, the furnace has to be manually reset (depending on model).

The vacuum switch will look something like this...

![Vacuum switch](https://i.stack.imgur.com/JuyoF.jpg)

And will have a rubber tube connecting it to the draft inducer. This part cannot be repaired, and must be replaced if it's faulty.

Pilot Not Igniting
------------------

If the pilot does not light, you'll first want to check to make sure there is something trying to ignite it. Typically a spark or glow ignitor is used, so first you'll want to determine which is being used.

### Glow Ignitor

A glow ignitor looks similar to this, though may not be visible without further disassembly.

![Glow ignitor](https://i.stack.imgur.com/m3OVd.jpg)

It works by passing a current through it, causing it to heat up and glow. It should heat up enough to ignite the pilot gas. If it doesn't heat up, it should be replaced.

### Spark Ignitor

A spark ignitor looks like this.

![Spark Ignitor](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KugBz.jpg)

Take notice of the thick, often orange or red wire that is typically used to connect the ignitor to the ignition control module. This device works by generating an electrical arc between the two probes, causing the pilot gas to ignite. If there is no spark, you'll have to replace the ignition control module and/or the ignitor itself. If the [ignitor is not igniting the gas](https://diy.stackexchange.com/q/32529/33), but there is a spark. You can try cleaning the electrodes with fine steel wool, to remove any carbon buildup.

Pilot Not Proving
-----------------

For a pilot to "prove", it simply means that the flame sensor has sensed the pilot flame. If there is no pilot or the sensor doesn't detect it, the furnace will often purge the system and then try again. Furnaces will often try a set number of times, before entering lock out.

If you can see the pilot flame, but the sensor is not detecting it. Try gently cleaning the sensor with fine steel wool, to remove any built up carbon. Also make sure the sensor is in the proper location with respect to the flame (Check the owners manual for proper placement), and adjust as necessary. If that doesn't work, replace the sensor.

Main Burner Not Proving
-----------------------

If the main burner ignites, but the furnace shuts down before the blower starts. You'll want to check the main flame (or rollout, high limit, etc) sensor(s). If your furnace has error code indicators, check those and compare to the owners manual for translation. In this case, you'll want to test and/or replace each sensor and/or contact an HVAC technician

\#\#\# User: Leak in pipe is barely above the concrete floor. If try to cut and solder will be too low. Any suggestions? Too close to concrete for SharkBite connections. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can solder a copper repair coupler over the hole. It's basically just like a sleeve. You don't have to cut the pipe near the concrete. 

Sand and flux the bottom inch of the copper pipe above the concrete. Cut off the copper pipe maybe 1 foot higher than the concrete, and drop a copper repair coupler that doesn't have an internal stop onto the pipe and slide it down to the top of the concrete. 

Next shorten the copper pipe enough to add a second copper coupler that does have internal stops. Sand and flux the pipe. Add the coupler, solder both couplers at the same time. 

The first coupler seals the leak, and the second coupler is needed to repair the pipe after cutting it. 

Make sure to sand and flux the inside of the couplers too.

Question: A plumber is dealing with a leak in a copper pipe that is located just above a concrete floor, making it difficult to cut and solder. Which of the following methods would be the most appropriate to repair this leak?

A) Use a SharkBite connection to join the pipe near the concrete floor
B) Cut the pipe at the leak and solder a new section directly above the concrete
C) Apply epoxy putty to seal the leak without cutting the pipe
D) Use a repair coupler without an internal stop to slide over the leak, then cut the pipe higher up and add a second coupler with internal stops

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because the documentation states that the pipe is too close to the concrete for SharkBite connections.

Option B is not feasible because the leak is too close to the concrete floor, making it difficult to cut and solder at that location.

Option C, while a potential temporary fix, is not mentioned in the documentation and may not provide a long-lasting solution.

Option D is the correct answer, as it aligns with the method described in the documentation. This approach allows the plumber to seal the leak without cutting near the concrete by sliding a repair coupler without an internal stop over the leak. Then, the pipe can be cut higher up and repaired with a second coupler that has internal stops, effectively addressing the issue while avoiding the complications of working too close to the concrete floor.

\#\#\# User: So I know that the emergency engine power (F) is less efficient than regular travel, i.e. it requires more fuel per distance traveled. Turning on the headlight also requires more fuel than having it off.

However, I can't tell whether or not going at speed 1 is more fuel\-efficient than speed 2\. For a given distance, speed 2 means fewer supplies used and less terror accrued, but what about fuel? Does it use more fuel or the same?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Speeds 1 and 2 are equally efficient in a given direction. Going backwards will consume the same amount of fuel per tick as going forwards, but you will be significantly slower.

See also [this answer](https://gaming.stackexchange.com/a/205549/107692) \-\- note the "Lights Off" data showing that half speed and full speed take you equally far on a single unit of fuel.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A captain of a spaceship is trying to optimize their fuel consumption while traveling a distance of 1000 units. They have the following options:
1. Travel at speed 1 with lights off
2. Travel at speed 2 with lights off
3. Travel at speed 1 with lights on
4. Travel at speed 2 with lights on
5. Use emergency engine power

Assuming all other factors (like supplies and terror) are irrelevant, which option or combination of options would result in the most fuel-efficient journey?

A) Option 1, as slower speed always consumes less fuel
B) Option 2, as it covers the distance faster while using the same amount of fuel as Option 1
C) A combination of Options 1 and 2 in any proportion, as they are equally fuel-efficient
D) Option 5, as emergency power is designed for critical situations and must be more efficient

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the documentation, speeds 1 and 2 are equally fuel-efficient when traveling in the same direction with lights off. The information states that "Speeds 1 and 2 are equally efficient in a given direction" and refers to data showing "that half speed and full speed take you equally far on a single unit of fuel." Therefore, any combination of Options 1 and 2 would result in the same fuel consumption for the given distance.

Option 3 and 4 are less efficient because turning on the headlight requires more fuel. Option 5 is incorrect because the documentation explicitly states that emergency engine power is less efficient and "requires more fuel per distance traveled."

Thus, the most fuel-efficient journey would involve any combination of traveling at speed 1 and speed 2 with the lights off.

- \sbox0 measures the width of a sample text in a tabular environment
- \sbox1 and \sbox2 measure the dimensions of the images to be used

These measurements are then used to calculate appropriate sizes for the table cells and ensure proper alignment and spacing in the final layout. This approach allows for dynamic sizing based on the content, rather than using fixed dimensions.

Option A is incorrect as the code doesn't involve coloring boxes. Option C is wrong because the code doesn't add borders to table cells. Option D is incorrect as there's no rotation of images in this code.

\#\#\# User: I’m using iOS 13\.2 on an iPhone X, and would like to drastically reduce the amount of cellular data my phone is using. In less than a month, my phone has used 10\.7 GB of cellular data. 8\.5 GB of that is from “System Services,” with 7\.9 GB coming from “Documents \& Sync.”

Is there any way to see what is using all of that data, or to control what happens over cellular vs waiting for Wi\-Fi? My battery also dies quickly, and assume that is related to how much cellular data is being used in background. 

What I tried: 

* I turned off iCloud Drive syncing over cellular network yesterday morning and then reset cellular data usage statistics. Since then, Documents \& Sync has used used 1\.0 GB of cellular data .
* I’ve had “Low Data Mode” turned on under Cellular Data Options for the entire month, which doesn’t seem to be helping at all.
* I tried erasing all content and settings and restoring from backup. This may have helped slightly, but it still seems to be using large amounts of cellular data

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Take a look at "Wi\-Fi Assist", which is found at Settings \-\-\> Cellular \-\-\> right near the bottom of the list. This setting uses your cellular data when Wi\-Fi connectivity is poor. 

This may account for cell usage even when you have iCloud Drive turned off.

33.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A user with an iPhone X running iOS 13.2 is experiencing high cellular data usage, particularly from "System Services" and "Documents & Sync". Which of the following settings is most likely contributing to this issue, even when iCloud Drive syncing over cellular network is turned off?

A) Low Data Mode
B) Wi-Fi Assist
C) iCloud Backup
D) Background App Refresh

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A) Low Data Mode is actually designed to reduce data usage, so it's not likely to be the cause of high data consumption.

B) Wi-Fi Assist, found at Settings -> Cellular -> near the bottom of the list, uses cellular data when Wi-Fi connectivity is poor. This can lead to unexpected cellular data usage even when the user thinks they're on Wi-Fi, making it the most likely culprit for the described issue.

C) iCloud Backup typically occurs when the device is connected to Wi-Fi and charging, so it's not likely to be causing high cellular data usage.

D) While Background App Refresh can use cellular data, it's not typically associated with the "Documents & Sync" category mentioned in the question, and it usually doesn't consume as much data as described.

The correct answer is B (Wi-Fi Assist) because it can cause the device to use cellular data even when the user believes they're connected to Wi-Fi, potentially explaining the high data usage from "System Services" and "Documents & Sync".

\#\#\# User: What is the cleanest, easiest way to explain someone the concept of variance? What does it intuitively mean? If one is to explain this to their child how would one go about it?

It's a concept that I have difficulty in articulating \- especially when relating variance to risk. I understand it mathematically and can explain it that way too. But when explaining real world phenomena how do you make one understand variance and it's applicability in the 'real world', so to speak.

Let's say we are simulating an investment in a stock using random numbers (rolling a die or using an excel sheet, doesn't matter). We get some 'return on investment' by associating each instance of the random variable to 'some change' in the return. Eg.: 

> Rolling a 1 implies a change of 0\.8 per \\$1 in investment, a 5 a change of 1\.1 per \\$1 and so on.

Now if this simulation is run for about 50 times (or 20 or 100\) we will get some values and the final value of the investment. So what does 'variance' actually tell us if we were to calculate it from the above data set? What does one "see" \- If the variance turns out to be 1\.7654 or 0\.88765 or 5\.2342 what does this even mean? What did/can I observe about this investment?? What conclusions can I draw \- in lay man terms.

Please feel free to augment the question with that for standard deviation too! Although I feel it's 'easier' to understand, but something that would contribute to making it also 'intuitively' clear would be greatly appreciated!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I would probably use a similar analogy to the one I've learned to give 'laypeople' when introducing the concept of bias and variance: the dartboard analogy. See below:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/YuksA.png)

The particular image above is from [Encyclopedia of Machine Learning](https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1007/978-0-387-30164-8), and the reference within the image is [Moore and McCabe's "Introduction to the Practice of Statistics"](https://books.google.ca/books/about/Introduction_to_the_Practice_of_Statisti.html?id=6qJpAAAAMAAJ&source=kp_book_description&redir_esc=y).

**EDIT:**

Here's an exercise that I believe is pretty intuitive: Take a deck of cards (out of the box), and drop the deck from a height of about 1 foot. Ask your child to pick up the cards and return them to you. Then, instead of dropping the deck, toss it as high as you can and let the cards fall to the ground. Ask your child to pick up the cards and return them to you.

The relative fun they have during the two trials should give them an intuitive feel for variance :)

34.answer:
Here's a multi-part exam question based on the provided information:

Question: A finance professor wants to explain the concept of variance to her students using a card-dropping experiment. She performs two trials:

Trial 1: Drops a deck of cards from a height of 1 foot.
Trial 2: Tosses the deck as high as possible.

After each trial, she measures the distance of each card from the point directly below where the deck was released. Which of the following statements is correct about the variance of these distance measurements?

A) The variance will be exactly the same in both trials, as the same deck of cards is used.

B) Trial 1 will have a higher variance because the cards are dropped from a lower height, causing them to spread out more.

C) Trial 2 will likely have a higher variance because the cards have more opportunity to spread out when tossed higher.

D) Variance cannot be calculated from this experiment because the number of cards in the deck is unknown.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Trial 2 will likely have a higher variance because when the cards are tossed higher, they have more time and space to spread out before landing. This increased dispersion of cards corresponds to a higher variance in their distances from the release point. 

In Trial 1, the cards are dropped from a lower height, giving them less opportunity to spread out, which would result in a lower variance. This experiment provides an intuitive understanding of variance as a measure of spread or dispersion in a dataset.

Option A is incorrect because the height and method of release significantly affect the spread of the cards. Option B incorrectly assumes that a lower drop height would increase variance. Option D is incorrect because variance can be calculated regardless of the exact number of cards, as long as we have the distance measurements.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Complete the sentence with the most appropriate verb form:
"Please add this record to the parcel ____________________."

A) if you found it
B) if you have found it
C) if you will find it
D) if you would find it

Correct Answer: B

Explanations:

A) "if you found it" is incorrect because it uses the simple past tense, which doesn't accurately convey the present relevance of the action.

B) "if you have found it" is correct. It uses the present perfect tense, which indicates an action completed in the past but with relevance to the present situation. This is the most appropriate choice for the context.

C) "if you will find it" is incorrect because it uses the future tense, which doesn't make sense in this context as the action of finding should precede adding the record.

D) "if you would find it" is incorrect because it uses a conditional form that doesn't fit the intended meaning and creates an awkward sentence structure.

The correct answer (B) best captures the idea that the parcel may have been found recently, and its discovery has a direct impact on the current action of adding the record.

\#\#\# User: Is there a way to move a file from a directory to another and then cd into the latter in one command? Something like `mv /a/file /another/dir && cd _` but without typing second time the directory path. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There are some functions for moving and copying files and following them to the destination directory originating from [a thread on the Arch Linux boards](https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?pid=697235#p697235):

```
# Follow copied and moved files to destination directory
cpf() { cp "$@" && goto "$_"; }
mvf() { mv "$@" && goto "$_"; }
goto() { [ -d "$1" ] && cd "$1" || cd "$(dirname "$1")"; }
```

You can then {move,copy} and follow a file by issuing:

```
mvf file /dest/dir/
```

I've been trying to find a setting in which I can point the Dropbox app to the existing location, but all I can find is a "move dropbox" setting. \#\#\# Top Answer: I've found a way around it.

Just rename the existing Dropbox folder to 'Dropbox\_' or similar. Pause Dropbox sync, set the location to the same folder, and click apply/ok. Delete that newly created folder and rename 'Dropbox\_' back to 'Dropbox'.

It's a bit sucky you got to do that but it does prevent having to re\-download everything you already have. Alternatively, make the folder, and just copy paste your entire old\-dropbox files into the new one. If it's on a different hard drive then that would take a while anyways.

\#\#\# User: I have software which is built using a makefile. This makefile also contains (relative) paths to different programs (such as gsoap, postgresql and others) which provide stuff that I need to include. In Windows, I simply download them and extract/install them wherever I want them to be. But for Ubuntu, I often find the recommendation is to use apt\-get to install software. 

According to stuff I've read, apt\-get doesn't install the programs into one directory, but splits them. That way I can't simply point to a directory where the makefile can find its stuff, right? How is that handled in Linux?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'll assume that you are talking about building/compiling C/C\+\+ software on Ubuntu. This isn't clear from your question.

On a modern Linux distribution with a package management system (which includes virtually all the major distributions), you should always use the package management system to install software whenever possible.

In a Linux distribution the library itself, and the so\-called "development" files required to build/compile against the library are usually packaged separately. These are often of the form `libname` (for the library), and `libname-dev` or `libname-devel` (for the "development" files). For C/C\+\+ the development files are header files.

These header files are usually installed in standard locations by the package, where the compiler can find them at build time. These locations are normally inside `/usr/include`. You usually don't have to do anything special to point your compiler to those locations \- it already knows about them.

38.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: When building software on Ubuntu using a makefile that includes paths to external programs and libraries, what is the recommended approach for handling dependencies?

A) Download and extract all required programs to a single directory and point the makefile to that location
B) Use apt-get to install programs, then manually locate and update the makefile with the scattered file locations
C) Install both the main library package and its corresponding development package using apt-get, relying on standard include paths
D) Avoid using apt-get and compile all dependencies from source code to ensure consistent file locations

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The correct approach is to use apt-get to install both the main library package and its corresponding development package (often named libname-dev). This method is recommended for several reasons:

1. It utilizes the package management system, which is the preferred method for installing software on Linux distributions.
2. The development packages install header files in standard locations (usually under /usr/include) that the compiler already knows about.
3. This approach doesn't require manually updating the makefile with specific paths, as the compiler can automatically find the necessary files.
4. It ensures that the installed libraries are compatible with the system and receive proper updates.

Option A is incorrect because it mimics the Windows approach, which isn't ideal for Linux systems. Option B is partially correct in using apt-get but unnecessarily complicates the process by requiring manual path updates. Option D is an extreme approach that bypasses the benefits of the package management system and can lead to compatibility issues.

\#\#\# User: ![System Services Screenshot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/eQUyzm.jpg)

How to turn off software updates?

![iTunes & App Store Settings](https://i.stack.imgur.com/7uzbZm.jpg)

![Cellular Settings](https://i.stack.imgur.com/t32t6m.jpg)

iPhone 6, iOS 8\.1\.1\. Everything seems to be turned off, still software updates is using the greatest amount of cell data. By resetting the stats we still see data being used.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer:  Fischer, there are two different types of software updates that occur on iOS; updates to the apps you have installed and updates to the operating system itself. 

 To disable app updates over your friend’s cellular connection, navigate to Settings → iTunes \& App Store and scroll to the very bottom. Tap the toggle next to “Use Cellular Data,” but keep in mind that this will also disable the use of iTunes Match and iTunes Radio over the phone’s cellular connection.

 If you are concerned about updates to iOS itself being installed over your friend’s cellular connection, don’t be — having contacted a friend of mine who is an Apple Genius, she tells me that your iPhone won’t install updates to your operating system without a connection to WiFi or the user’s specific permission.

 If your friend continues to have an issue, she may want to contact Apple about a potential bug.

\#\#\# User: I've been looking into reverse polarity protection and come across a lot of resources that recommend using a P\-channel MOSFET with a Zener diode.

Every single one of these circuits shows the MOSFET reversed \- as if current was flowing from drain\-\>source, when in reality the current in P\-FETs flows from source\-\>drain.

Some of the articles even have a comment that echoes my confusion. Am I actually missing something here or is there some reason why all of these circuits seem incorrect?

A few examples:

* [This one](https://circuitdigest.com/electronic-circuits/reverse-polarity-protection-circuit-diagram)

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/L7ztr.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/L7ztr.png)

* [That one](https://components101.com/articles/design-guide-pmos-mosfet-for-reverse-voltage-polarity-protection)

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/S7b2V.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/S7b2V.png)

* [This other one](https://hackaday.com/2011/12/06/reverse-voltage-protection-with-a-p-fet/)

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/tQpWS.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/tQpWS.png)

If these circuits **are** wrong, then I assume it's more than just the MOSFET being reversed, and the Zener diode should still be between the source and gate. Is that correct?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This circuit looks odd the first time you see it. When a MOSFET (P or N\-channel) is on it conducts in both directions.

But, in order for a discrete MOSFET to block current, the body diode must be reverse\-biased. The circuits you linked to are correct. When the power supply is connected properly, the MOSFET will be held on and will conduct with low resistance.

If the MOSFET in one of those circuits were to be reversed, it would still work in the forward direction. But then in reverse polarity, even though the MOSFET would be biased "off" by gate voltage, the body diode would be forward biased. So the MOSFET would conduct via the body diode and the main purpose of the circuit would be defeated.

41.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a reverse polarity protection circuit using a P-channel MOSFET, why is the MOSFET oriented with its source terminal connected to the positive supply voltage, despite the fact that current in P-FETs typically flows from source to drain?

A) The circuit diagrams are incorrect and the MOSFET should be reversed.
B) This orientation allows the body diode to be reverse-biased during normal operation, enabling proper protection.
C) The Zener diode forces current to flow in the opposite direction through the MOSFET.
D) P-channel MOSFETs always conduct from drain to source, regardless of orientation.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct orientation of the P-channel MOSFET in reverse polarity protection circuits, with its source connected to the positive supply, may seem counterintuitive at first. However, this configuration is essential for proper circuit operation. When the power supply is connected correctly, the MOSFET is held on and conducts with low resistance in both directions. More importantly, this orientation ensures that the MOSFET's body diode is reverse-biased during normal operation. If the polarity is reversed, the body diode remains reverse-biased, and the MOSFET turns off, preventing current flow and protecting the circuit. If the MOSFET were reversed, its body diode would conduct in reverse polarity conditions, defeating the purpose of the protection circuit.

\#\#\# User: I flagged both [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17700722/parsing-json-data-in-android/17700893#17700893) and [that](https://stackoverflow.com/a/17161107/368354) answers for "very low quality". The former because it's just a link without even a minimal summary, and the second because it isn't comprehensible whatsoever. Both were declined with "flags should not be used to indicate technical inaccuracies, or an altogether wrong answer". I haven't even flagged them for that reason, especially since I thought it's *encouraged* to flag link\-only answers as VLQ. And the latter answer is definitely not "salvageable through editing".

So why were these declined? I have flagged a lot answers of both types as VLQ, that were usually accepted quickly.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I declined both those flags, because they were `very low quality` flags against posts that were not `Very low quality` by our definition.

Very low quality [has a very specific](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/93595/is-the-very-low-quality-flag-too-ambiguous/93606#93606) [meaning](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/95581/the-limits-to-a-very-low-quality-answer/95641#95641) (and it's used for the review queue, [so it needs to be handled strictly](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/160754/why-are-the-moderators-being-so-strict-with-quality-related-flags-recently)). When you're flagging a post as `Very Low Quality`, it's as if you're saying the following:

> This content should not exist. Delete it. Now. It is not salvageable through editing.

Put another way, if I'm not comfortable outright deleting a post, I'm going to decline the VLQ flag.

The two posts you listed were bad, but for different reasons, 1 [was a link only answer](https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/183658/16587), and the other was just a short answer with bad punctuation. 

Both were salvageable through editing. 

If you had [flagged this post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17700722/parsing-json-data-in-android/17700893#17700893) as "User asked to expand on link; did not. Flagging for deletion." I would have accepted it (it shows effort to engage, [which is really important in building and maintaining a community](https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/183676/16587)).

If you're flagging something as `Very Low Quality`, so long as you follow the above criteria, you'll be ok.

The Very Low Quality flag reason *is not* and *cannot* be a proxy for removing a question or answer that should be removed or closed a question for other reasons. It's a shortcut to the Moderator team, so we have to make sure it's not being abused or used as a proxy to get around community moderation.
